Merav studies the effects of global change on a variety of animals including the effects of invasive lake trout on river otters in #Yellowstone Lake and population status and distribution of spotted skunks in #Wyoming. The campaign team likes to joke that Merav has a photo with every animal (even this skunk!), so leave a comment with your favorite, and Merav will try to find a photo with it! #forthefutureofwyoming #VoteMerav #ThatsWY

Last week 300 coal miners were laid-off in the Powder River Basin. Oil companies are expected to dismiss at least 100 of their workers in #Wyoming. The economic consequences are hard to predict without understanding of the rate at which stored oil will be used and the prospects of re-opening some of the wells. Our priority should be to protect our workers and their families. #forthefutureofwyoming

Great News!!! We only need to change the Hearts and Minds of 56,000 voters in Wyoming! We are often asked why run for office as a Democrat in Wyoming? It is such a red state! The reality - in Wyoming we need to reach relatively few people.  The graph displays the number of non-democratic voters needed to vote for a Democratic candidate, in order to win any of these Senate Seats. Wyoming Wins with the lowest number of non-Dem voters needed to convince! But - we still need YOUR help to win the hearts and minds of friends and neighbors. This week for #MeetMeravMonday, we want to get serious. When Merav lived in Alaska working on her Ph.D., she had her first experiences learnings what it means to belong to a minority group and what Anti-Semitism looks like. She will fight for your rights as a minority in #Wyoming. We should be inclusive of people with differing backgrounds, beliefs, and orientations. "I have an ethical problem with privatizing prisons. I think making money off of imprisonment of people is morally incorrect and I’m very happy to see that the proposed prison plan in Evanston is halted. I think our plan should be to rehabilitate people where possible and only remove people who are a danger to society from our streets. Privatized prisons turn imprisonment into a profitable business which can lead to abuse of peoples’ rights."

Happy #MeetMeravMonday! Merav learned to ride on 2 old family mares, but for her “Bat Mitzva” when she was 12, her father bought her a horse; an Arabian filly. She was adorable at first but turned into a terror when they started riding her. On every excursion, Merav ended up hanging from a tree branch, underneath her, or several meters away in the bushes. Watching bucking horse riders get hurt during our rodeos, she wonders how she never broke a bone in all the years owning this horse. #wyoming #votemerav #forthefutureofwyoming

COVID-19 highlighted several needs of Native American #Wyomingites. Although solving the housing shortage will take time, it should be a priority for the Federal Government. Don't be shy, ask your local and regional neighbors if they need help during this time. The Cheyenne supercomputer houses a massive dataset that is widely used by the climate and atmospheric research community to study phenomena like extreme rainfall, ice loss, and extended droughts in North America. AND the data is freely available on the commercial cloud!  Think of how more facilities like this could impact our economy - let's bring them here! #forthefutureofwyoming #wyoming #keepwywy

Thank you to Charles Gaba for making time to speak with me about COVID-19 and what it means for our health care system. Moving forward, I hope Governor Mark Gordon considered the possibility of calling and emergency and expanding Medicaid in #Wyoming.

University of Wyoming students rock! Excellent use of the knowledge gained at our one and only university. Thank you! Did you know that much of the world’s climate monitoring is made possible by the supercomputer in Cheyenne? What great technology and data we have right here in our backyard. #wyoming

I hear that people are doing #seeapupsendapup! Here are my two pups: Chilkoot and Togwotee!  Chilkoot (the first photo)  is descended from a kennel owned by Mary Shields, the first woman to complete the Iditarod Trail. Togwotee (second photo) is 25% coyote and will be 15 in July.
#WhereInWYIsDave? In our locally loved outdoor playground, Vedauwoo in Medicine Bow National Forest! We are so blessed to enjoy such beautiful #publiclands here in #Wyoming.

Friends and neighbors. Our health care professionals in Wyoming are running out of N95 masks and are re-using old ones for 3 days at a time. This is dangerous for them and their non-COVID19 patients. They can use any N95 masks though. So if you have an N95 mask (or more), let us know! We’ll set up collection sites in every town and distribute them. And please spread the word to EVERYONE.

Wyomingites! As we reduce our in-person activities and move to online interactions, as schools and businesses are temporarily closing, and as we restrict our travel locally, across state lines and internationally, the question “what will be the economic fallout of COVID-19 for Wyoming?” is bubbling to the surface. We are reaching out to solicit questions from you that our team will pose to Dr. Jay Shogren in a videotaped session that we will post and livestream. Dr. Shogren is a world renowned economist and a Nobel Peace Prize winner (for his work on the climate crisis with the IPCC) who teaches at the University of Wyoming (he is also an awesome musician). Please send your questions as soon as possible. Thanks!Wyomingnites! As we reduce our in-person activities and move to online interactions, as schools and businesses are temporarily closing, and as we restrict our travel locally, across state lines and internationally, the question “what will be the economic fallout of COVID-19 for Wyoming?” is bubbling to the surface. I am writing to solicit questions from you that my team will pose to Dr. Jay Shogren in a videotaped session that we will post and livestream. Dr. Shogren is a world renowned economist and a Nobel Peace Prize winner (for his work on the climate crisis with the IPCC) who teaches at the University of Wyoming (he is also an awesome musician). Please send your questions as soon as possible. Thanks!

Did you know that employees working in construction, extraction, farming, fishing, and forestry are the least likely to have paid sick leave? While some businesses and states have implemented programs, many Wyomingites mays struggle.

Much of the stress around COVID-19 comes down to the infrastructure of our healthcare system. Rural medicine faces many challenges, especially a time of pandemic. The establishment of the Respiratory Symptom Screening Clinic, which will support and provide service for patients of multiple respiratory infections, is a great asset to Wyoming.

About 50 percent of the revenue the state gets to pay for services like education comes from the minerals industry. But Wyoming has gotten less money from its minerals in recent years due to the decline of the coal industry, and on the day the budget was signed, global oil prices dropped. "This may be the last year we kick the can down the road do you think? I don't know," Senate Revenue Committee Chairman Cale Case said. Let’s stop reacting and get proactive by diversifying our portfolio!

As I said in my video yesterday, now is an opportunity to support Wyoming businesses while increasing use of technology.  Things you can do: 1) Shop online or via phone. While some stores already have online shopping, others will help customers order via phone or FaceTime. (Laramie's Basecamp has set a great example for local businesses.)  2) If you typically use local businesses to fill wholesale orders, place those requests as soon as possible. 3) Buy gift cards to use at a later date to support businesses now, even if you don't currently need anything. 4) Order takeout or delivery and tip the same amount as you would dining in.
Wash your hands, take care of yourself, and stay connected.

I am a wildlife ecologist who has been studying the various effects of global change (invasive species, logging, pollution, and climate change) on animals (river otters, martens, chipmunks and polar bears). While studying mountain lions in California in the early 2000s, my colleagues and I detected the increasing signal of anthropogenic carbon emissions over the past 150 years in their bones!

As other states and nations take climate action, Wyoming is at risk of economic distress from a waning extraction sector. Over the decades many flourishing US industries have disappeared, including the fur industry that contributed to the establishment of the state of Wyoming (the Louisiana Purchase) and the famous whaling industry. Learn about the rise and fall of the whaling industry in this interesting article from the Smithsonian Institution. https://americanhistory.si.edu/onthewater/exhibition/3_7.html?fbclid=IwAR1mkm2jn0pAKRX4mPi2fINshEh6L5_lFxK2EJ2lt7BvQCxTUqaNvykn21c

I would like to thank the trustees for making the decision to hire Dr. Seidel as the next president of the University of Wyoming. In addition to an impressive academic and leadership record, Dr. Seidel was the most inspiring of three good candidates. His vision for the future of UW and its role in leading the necessary changes to Wyoming’s economy are refreshing. During my interactions with him, it was clear that Dr. Seidel is familiar with the issues we face and is ready to take on this challenge. Finally, given his interest in outdoor activities it appears that Dr. Seidel will be a good fit for UW. I would like to welcome Dr. Seidel to Wyoming and look forward to working with him in the years to come.

You may be wondering why I say climate change will hit Wyoming's economy the hardest. The technology to replace coal, oil, and gas with alternative energy sources is advancing in leaps and bounds across much of the planet. When the price of coal, oil, and gas declines below the cost of production, this sector will wane, along with the bulk of Wyoming’s revenue. We are watching the beginning as coal mines and coal-fired power plants are closing and our communities are losing residents and loved ones. These are issues that matter to me, a Wyomingite. Methane gas has a shorter half life, but is a more potent greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide. An important climate change topic for Wyoming with our large fossil fuel industry #ForTheFutureofWyoming "Methane is the second most important greenhouse gas, after carbon dioxide, and while in the atmosphere causes far more intense warming — but over a much shorter period of time. Carbon dioxide can stay in the atmosphere for hundreds of years. Yet within about a decade, most methane in the atmosphere breaks down (into carbon dioxide and water). This means that capping methane can provide a quick curb to the planet’s warming. But that isn’t happening — instead, concentrations have been rising. Fast."
Exciting opportunities! With the right investment we can bring similar innovation to Wyoming.  #ForTheFutureofWyoming

"I have an ethical problem with privatizing prisons. I think making money off of imprisonment of people is morally incorrect and I’m very happy to see that the proposed prison plan in Evanston is halted. Did you know that employees working in construction, extraction, farming, fishing, and forestry are the least likely to have paid sick leave? While some businesses and states have implemented programs, many Wyomingites mays struggle.

About 50 percent of the revenue the state gets to pay for services like education comes from the minerals industry. But Wyoming has gotten less money from its minerals in recent years due to the decline of the coal industry, and on the day the budget was signed, global oil prices dropped. "This may be the last year we kick the can down the road do you think? I don't know," Senate Revenue Committee Chairman Cale Case said. Let’s stop reacting and get proactive by diversifying our portfolio!
Working hard to make sure we are still answering your questions while protecting your health, with our new furry friend Dave!

As I said in my video yesterday, now is an opportunity to support Wyoming businesses while increasing use of technology.  Things you can do: 1) Shop online or via phone. While some stores already have online shopping, others will help customers order via phone or FaceTime. (Laramie's Basecamp has set a great example for local businesses.)  2) If you typically use local businesses to fill wholesale orders, place those requests as soon as possible. 3) Buy gift cards to use at a later date to support businesses now, even if you don't currently need anything. 4) Order takeout or delivery and tip the same amount as you would dining in.
